Description: Twin-handled jar of slightly elongated proportions: the body is opaque dark blue, a colour found again on the handles, one of which is incomplete. On the neck is a chevron pattern in opaque yellow and white, colours which are repeated in the loose festoons of the body. An interesting technical detail, also present on a few other vessels, is a register of shallow indentations directly above the upper level of the body decorations.
Curator's comments: The indentations on the body of the jar were the guidepoints made when the vessel was viscous immediately prior to applying the decorations. One of the rare examples of a glass vessel found in a modest burial of the New Kingdom. Within the Eighteenth Dynasty at least, glass vessels seem to have been restricted chiefly to the court circle. Bibliography: W. M. F. Petrie, ‘Kahun, Gurob and Hawara’ (London 1890), 32, 38; B. Nolte, ‘Die Glasgefässe in Alten Ägypten (Berlin 1968), 108, pl. XV, 28; J.H. Taylor and N.C. Strudwick, Mummies: Death and the Afterlife in Ancient Egypt. Treasures from The British Museum, Santa Ana and London 2005, p. 167, pl. on p. 167. D. Antoine and M. Vandenbeusch, Egyptian mummies. Exploring ancient lives, Sydney 2016, pp. 132-2.
Bibliographic references: Taylor & Strudwick 2005 / Mummies: Death and the Afterlife in Ancient Egypt (p.167)
Tait 1991 / Five Thousand Years of Glass (fig.26, pp.30-31)
